noun.description: A compulsory contribution to state revenue, levied by the government on workers' income and business profits, or added to the cost of some goods, services, and transactions.

examples: a heavy tax on the reader's attention

verb.description: Impose a tax on (someone or something)
examples: hardware and software is taxed at 7.5 percent

verb.description: Make heavy demands on (someone's powers or resources)
examples: she knew that the ordeal to come would tax all her strength

verb.description: Confront (someone) with a fault or wrongdoing.
examples: why are you taxing me with these preposterous allegations?

verb.description: Examine and assess (the costs of a case).

origin: Middle English (also in the sense estimate or determine the amount of a penalty or damages, surviving in tax (sense 4 of the verb)): from Old French taxer, from Latin taxare to censure, charge, compute, perhaps from Greek tassein fix.
